reasoning: First off, streaming video is outside my circle of competence – I understand soft drinks, insurance, railroads and simple consumer merch, but not high-stakes content licensing and subscription wars. Second, Netflix’s moat looks shaky: yes, they’ve shown strong operating margins around 36%, but inconsistent ROE (just 0 of 10 years above 15%) and fierce competition from Amazon, Disney and others mean pricing power is far from assured. Third, management has driven subscriber growth, but the recent equity issuance dilutes owners and there’s no dividend – capital allocation hasn’t been particularly owner-friendly. Fourth, financially they carry a hefty debt-to-equity of 0.8, weak ROE of 10%, and uneven earnings growth; that’s a financial fortress I wouldn’t want to storm. Fifth, at a current price that implies an 84% negative margin of safety versus a conservative intrinsic value of $357, I’d be overpaying for a fair business rather than buying a wonderful business at a fair price. Finally, in comparison to what I already own – Coca-Cola, Apple, BNSF and GEICO – there’s nothing here that beats those high-quality, durable-moat franchises. I’ll pass.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 10.0%; High debt to equity ratio of 0.8; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 231.9% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 36.3%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (78.8%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (3.6%, 5y), Stage 2 (1.8%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
